Name: 3,7-Dimethylxanthine
Description: Theobromine is a dimethylxanthine having the two methyl groups located at positions 3 and 7. A purine alkaloid derived from the cacao plant, it is found in chocolate, as well as in a number of other foods, and is a vasodilator, diuretic and heart stimulator. It has a role as an adenosine receptor antagonist, a food component, a plant metabolite, a human blood serum metabolite, a mouse metabolite, a vasodilator agent and a bronchodilator agent.

plant_concentrations.References: (1) IARC; Coffee, tea, mate, methylxanthines, methylglyoxal. IARC Monograph on the Evaluation of the Carcinogenic Risk of Chemicals to Humans. Lyon, France: Int Agency Res Cancer 51: 421 (1991) (2) Zoumas BL, Smullen JF; Chocolate and Cocoa. Kirk-Othmer Encyclopedia of Chemical Technology. (1999-2016). New York, NY: John Wiley & Sons. Online Posting Date: 13 Apr 2012 (3) Balentine DA; Tea. Kirk-Othmer Encyclopedia of Chemical Technology. (1999-2016). New York, NY: John Wiley & Sons. Online Posting Date: 16 Feb 2007
plant_concentrations.Value: Theobromine concentration in whole cacao husks and beans are 0.7-1.2% and 1.5-3%, respectively(1). Levels of 20 mg/kg have been reported in green coffee beans(1). The concentration of theobromine in cocoa beans varies widely depending on country of origin, i.e., Trinidad, 1.730 and New Guinea, 0.818% total alkaloid(2). The quantity in fresh tea leaves has been reported as 0.2 weight% on a dry weight basis(3).

plant_concentrations.References: (1) US Dept Agric; US Dept Agric, Agric Res Service. 1992-2016. Dr. Duke's Phytochemical and Ethnobotanical Databases. Theobromine. Available from, as of Oct 20, 2016: https://phytochem.nal.usda.gov/phytochem/search
